column1: By Patricia Zengerle and Roberta Rampton
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON President Barack Obama on Friday vetoed legislation allowing families of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks to sue Saudi Arabia
column2: which could prompt Congress to overturn his decision with a rare veto override
column3: the first of his presidency.Obama said the Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act would hurt U.S. national security and harm important alliances
column4: while shifting crucial terrorism-related issues from policy officials into the hands of the courts.The bill passed the Senate and House of Representatives in reaction to long-running suspicions
column5: denied by Saudi Arabia
column6: that hijackers of the four U.S. jetliners that attacked the United States in 2001 were backed by the Saudi government.Fifteen of the 19 hijackers were Saudi nationals.Obama said other countries could use the law
column8: as an excuse to sue U.S. diplomats
column9: members of the military or companies - even for actions of foreign organizations that had received U.S. aid
column10: equipment or training.""Removing sovereign immunity in U.S. courts from foreign governments that are not designated as state sponsors of terrorism
column11: based solely on allegations that such foreign governments' actions abroad had a connection to terrorism-related injuries on U.S. soil
column12: threatens to undermine these longstanding principles that protect the United States
column15: Obama said in a statement.Senator Chuck Schumer
column16: who co-wrote the legislation and has championed it
column17: immediately made clear how difficult it will be for Obama to sustain the veto.Schumer
column18: the No. 3 Democrat in the Senate
column19: issued a statement within moments of receiving the veto
column20: promising that it would be ""swiftly and soundly overturned."" He represents New York
column21: home of most of the Sept. 11 victims.

column1: Both the Democratic and Republican candidates for president
column2: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump
column3: said they would have signed the bill into law if they were in the White House.SOME DOUBTS

column1: If two-thirds of the lawmakers in both the Senate and House vote to override
column2: the law would stand
column3: the first such override since he became president in 2009
column4: and possibly the last.

column1: Obama leaves office in January. Friday's veto was the twelfth of his presidency.An override has been expected
column2: despite some lawmakers saying they had doubts about the measure.In a letter seen by Reuters on Friday
column3: Republican Representative Mac Thornberry
column4: chairman of the powerful House Armed Services Committee
column5: said he would oppose the override.""My primary concern is that this bill increases the risk posed to American military and intelligence personnel
column6: diplomats and others serving our country around the world
column7: Thornberry wrote in a letter encouraging his fellow Republicans to sustain the veto.

column1: House Speaker Paul Ryan said Wednesday he thought there were enough votes to override a veto
column2: but had concerns. ""I worry about trial lawyers trying to get rich off of this. And I do worry about the precedent
column3: he told reporters.The ""9/11 Families & Survivors United for Justice Against Terrorism"" group
column4: which has pressed Congress to uphold the legislation
column5: called Obama's veto explanation ""unconvincing and unsupportable.""The Saudi government has lobbied heavily to stop the bill
column6: the European Union has formally opposed it and Gulf States have condemned it.Major U.S. corporations such as General Electric and Dow Chemical have also pressed lawmakers to reconsider.""The bill is not balanced
column8: and has real potential to destabilize vital bilateral relationships and the global economy
column9: GE Chief Executive Jeffrey Immelt said in a letter to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell
column10: who supports the bill. (Reporting by Roberta Rampton and Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Grant McCool)"	['Paul'

column2: winning over women will be key	"

column1: By Ginger Gibson
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON When Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton face off in their first presidential debate together on Monday
column2: they will have their best chance yet to win over the roughly 27 million Americans who have yet to decide who to vote for.In some ways
column3: this group looks like a typical Trump supporter: they are mainly white
column4: without college degrees
column5: older
column6: and frustrated by the status quo. But while Trump's supporters are mostly men
column7: America's uncommitted voters are mostly women
column8: according to Reuters/Ipsos polling.With polls showing a close fight between Trump and Hillary
column9: this is a group that could decide the election. Katie Packer
column10: a Republican strategist who served as a top aide to Mitt Romney in 2012 said polls show that many undecided women have been put off by Trump's inflammatory rhetoric
column12: the first female presidential candidate from a major U.S. party
column13: as dishonest.""These are the same women who don't trust Hillary and think she's phony
column14: she said. ""But Trump is scary to them.""    Roughly 20 percent of America's likely voters are still on the fence
column15: compared to just 12 percent at the same time in the 2012 election
column16: underscoring the unpopularity of both Trump and Clinton. Some 77 percent of them think the country is on the ""wrong track
column17: which puts them more in line with Trump supporters than Clinton backers. They are also similar in age to many Trump backers: some 54 percent are at least 55 years old. And 67 percent never earned a college degree
column18: compared with 71 percent for Trump supporters and 56 percent for Clinton supporters.Gender-wise
column19: they track more closely with Clinton's base. Some 60 percent are women. Trump's base is made up of about 48 percent women

column1: The most recent Reuters/Ipsos poll found Clinton leading Trump by 4 percentage points in a two-way race. The Democratic nominee has mostly led Trump in the poll this year
column2: but the gap between the two candidates has narrowed with six weeks left before the Nov. 8 election. TORN

column1: With neither candidate a clear favorite on issues like creating jobs or keeping the nation safe
column2: nearly a third of uncommitted voters said they may be more likely to vote for a third-party candidate than for either Clinton or Trump.""One of the most important issues in this election is just making sure that our country has a future both through education and jobs
column3: said undecided voter Erika Szotek
column5: of Hanover Park
column6: Illinois

column1: She said she thought Trump's ""flamboyancy is going to get the country into a lot of trouble with other countries."" But she isn't sold on Clinton either. ""There are some things I just don't trust about her."" Women have been a lingering problem for Trump
column2: whose unfiltered speaking style and fiery rhetoric on immigration and security have put many off. He has also gotten into trouble for some remarks he has made about women.He was widely criticized for saying Fox News host Megyn Kelly had ""blood coming out of her wherever
column3: a comment many interpreted as referring to her menstruating
column4: although he insisted that was not what he meant. He has also called television personality Rosie O'Donnell a ""fat pig"" and made fun of former presidential rival and ex-Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina's face
column5: saying
column6: ""Would anyone vote for that?""

column1: Clinton's campaign has seized on the vulnerability. This week it launched an ad titled ""Mirrors"" that shows images of girls looking in mirrors while recordings of Trump comment on women's weight and breast size
column2: calling them ""slob
column3: ""pig
column4: and ""fat.""  But Clinton has her own troubles.Multiple polls show that her use of a private email server without approval while secretary of state has deepened voters' mistrust of her even though she has since acknowledged it was a mistake. Trump frequently calls her ""Crooked Hillary.""FBI director James Comey recommended in July that no criminal charges be brought against Clinton for her handling of classified information while she was secretary of state
column5: but he called her use of the server ""extremely careless.""    Ruth Hammett
column9: said she would be looking to the debates for guidance on which candidate to support. She is leaning toward Clinton but wants to hear both candidates address national security.   ""I'm very scared
column10: most so for my kids and my grandkids
column11: Hammett said. ""I'm scared to death."" (Reporting by Ginger Gibson and Chris Kahn; Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Ross Colvin)"	['Romney'

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN11T2F4	Clinton leads Trump by 4 points ahead of first presidential debate: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Democrat Hillary Clinton had a four-percentage point advantage in support over Republican Donald Trump ahead of their first U.S. presidential debate
column2: according to the latest Reuters/Ipsos national tracking poll released on Friday.The Sept. 16-22 opinion poll showed that 41 percent of likely voters supported Clinton
column3: while 37 percent supported Trump. Clinton has mostly led Trump in the poll during the 2016 campaign
column4: though her advantage has narrowed since the end of the Democratic and Republican national conventions in July.With just six weeks before the Nov. 8 election
column5: Monday's debate at Hofstra University in Hempstead
column6: New York will be the first of three between the White House rivals. It presents a major opportunity for them to appeal to voters who have yet to commit to a candidate after a mostly negative race in which Clinton and Trump have sought to brand each other as untrustworthy and dangerous for the country.The live
column7: televised matchup is expected to draw a Super Bowl-sized television audience of 100 million Americans

column1: Among those watching will be people who so far remain on the fence. This could be a sizable group: Some 22 percent of likely voters said in the latest poll that they do not support either major-party candidate. That was more than twice the proportion of uncommitted voters at the same point in the 2012 election between Democratic President Barack Obama and Republican Mitt Romney.These uncommitted voters appear to be leaning more toward Trump than Clinton
column2: according to the latest poll
column3: though they have not been convinced enough to say they will vote for him in November. It was also possible that some of these voters would pick an alternative-party candidate like Libertarian Gary Johnson or the Green Party's Jill Stein.

column1: Clinton led a separate four-way poll that included Trump
column2: Johnson and Stein. Among likely voters
column3: 39 percent supported Clinton
column4: 37 percent favored Trump
column5: 7 percent picked Johnson and 2 percent supported Stein.The Reuters/Ipsos poll is conducted online in English in the continental United States
column6: Alaska and Hawaii. It included 1
column7: 559 respondents who were considered to be likely voters given their voting history
column8: registration status and stated intention to show up on Election Day. It has a credibility interval
column11: meaning results could vary by that much either way.

column1: National polls have produced varying measurements of support for Clinton and Trump during the 2016 campaign. The differences are partly due to the fact that some polls
column2: like Reuters/Ipsos
column3: try to include only likely voters
column4: while others include all registered voters. The Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll gathers responses every day and reports results twice a week
column5: so it often detects trends in sentiment before most other polls. Polling aggregators
column6: which calculate averages of major polls
column7: have shown that Clinton's lead over Trump has been shrinking this month. The most recent individual polls put her advantage at 3 percentage points. (Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Jonathan Oatis)"	['Romney'

column1: By Roberta Rampton
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON The White House budget office scheduled a call with U.S government agencies on Friday to plan for a government shutdown in case the U.S. Congress fails to pass a short-term funding bill by a deadline next week.""It is our hope that this work will ultimately be unnecessary and that there will be no lapse in appropriations
column2: a spokeswoman for the White House Office of Management and Budget (OMB) said in a statement.The federal fiscal year ends on Sept. 30 and Congress must pass a spending measure by then to keep the government open. In recent years
column3: lawmakers have seldom agreed on a full federal budget and instead have relied on stop-gap measures.

column1: On Thursday
column2: Republicans produced a bill which Democrats immediately rejected. The Senate is expected to hold an initial procedural vote on the legislation on Tuesday
column3: according to a senior Republican aide. The White House was pleased that bill includes funding to fight the Zika virus
column4: but has concerns about other provisions
column5: spokesman Josh Earnest said
column6: noting that it was ""too soon to panic"" about the bill.

column1: I think it is unclear at best right now whether or not this particular piece of legislation will pass both houses of Congress and make its way to the president's desk. Even if it were
column2: it's also unclear at best right now if the president would sign it
column3: Earnest told reporters.The OMB said there was enough time for Congress to pass a short-term funding bill
column4: but ""prudent management requires that the government plan for the possibility of a lapse.""

column1: Republicans and Democrats annually fight about spending bills but normally reach a deal to avert a shutdown
column2: particularly during election years. In 2013
column3: the two sides failed to agree
column4: and the government stopped operations for 16 days. (Additional reporting by Ayesha Rascoe and David Morgan; Editing by Bernadette Baum and Sandra Maler)"	[]	[]

BERLIN Activists from the online campaign group Avaaz tore down a cardboard wall near the site of the former Berlin Wall on Friday to urge American expats in Germany to vote against Republican nominee Donald Trump in the U.S. election on Nov. 8.Many identify Trump with his proposal to build a huge border wall between the United States and Mexico to keep migrants out; moreover
column2: the event was staged in front of the Brandenburg Gate
column3: near the place where U.S. president Ronald Reagan publicly urged Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in 1987 to ""tear down this wall"".Holding red and blue placards saying ""Stop Trump"" and ""Tear Down Trump's Wall""

column5: emblazoned with a picture of Trump
column6: with their hands and rubber mallets.Many of the 150 or so onlookers chanted ""The wall must come down!"" as it was knocked over.

WASHINGTON Donald Trump on Friday named U.S. Senator Mike Lee as a potential Supreme Court nominee
column2: turning to an ally of former rival Ted Cruz in an apparent gesture to conservative Republicans who have been wary of the Republican presidential candidate. column3: Trump said in a statement.The announcement came out on a day in which neither candidate had a public event and were preparing for Monday's first presidential debate.The list Trump announced included 10 new names and 11 conservative jurists from a list the New York businessman had announced in May. Lee's brother
